newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian stocks end lower, led by cement stocks.
newsitem.headline: Colombian stocks end lower, led by cement stocks.

text.p: Colombian stocks ended lower as cement shares fell on profit-taking and concerns about this week's move by Mexico's Cemex to grab controlling interest in another Colombian cement manfacturer.
Medellin's IBOMED general price index dropped 0.95 percent to 13,149.30 on a lower-than-average volume of 660 million pesos. Bogota's IBB fell 0.47 percent, ending the day at 847.76.
Volume in Bogota, totalling 2.2 billion pesos, was inflated by a cross trade of 900 million pesos of shares in the Suramericana de Seguros insurance company, brokers said.
Suramericana, part of the powerful Sindicato Antioqueno industrial group, closed unchanged at 18,000 pesos per share.

Banco Ganadero has posted steady gains over the last week in the run-up to next week's deal in which a 40 percent stake in the bank will be sold to Banco Bilbao Vizcaya of Spain. Its preferential shares dropped 2.22 percent in Thursday's trade, however, ending at 220 pesos a share.
Banco de Colombia slipped lower as well, ending down 1.14 percent at 430 pesos a share. But Banco de Bogota extended its previous day's gains, closing up 0.18 percent at 5,560 pesos per share.
The day's biggest loser was Cementos Paz del Rio, which fell 8.75 percent to close at 800 pesos a share in Bogota. It was joined by Cementos Caribe, which shed 3.97 percent of its share value.

Some brokers attributed the drop to profit taking. But others pointed out Cemex's purchase of Industrias e Inversiones Samper earlier this week has put in a position to become a dominant player in the Colombian cement market.
Cemex, the world's third-largest cement company, had already purchased controlling interest in Cementos Diamante earlier this year. -- Javier Mozzo, Bogota newsroom, 571 610 7944
